title: Unlocking Orbital-Driven Peierls Dimerization: Atomic-Scale Insights into the Unconventional Metal-to-Metal Phase Transition in NaRu2O4
content: In recent years, ruthenium-based transition metal compounds have attracted considerable attention in the field of quantum materials and strongly correlated electron systems. The reason for this is their moderate spin-orbit coupling, which is neither too weak nor too strong compared to the Coulomb interaction U. Due to this interplay, the relatively heavy 4d transition metal ruthenates exhibit a number of unusual properties compared to 3d transition metals, including unconventional superconductivity, metal-insulator transitions, high-temperature ferromagnetism, Haldane chains, and orbital ordering. The interdependence between localized and itinerant electrons, together with the orbital degrees of freedom in ruthenate systems, results in a greater diversity of electronic and magnetic properties [1, 2]. Despite this potential of Na-Ru-O systems as a model to study electron correlations in mixed-valence 4d systems, research in this area remains sparse.
